# Complex Geometry

# Types and Constructions of Vector Bundles

# Pullback Bundles

Let p:L→Yp : \mathcal{L} \rightarrow Yp:L→Y be a vector bundle with fibre FFF, and let f:X→Yf : X \rightarrow Yf:X→Y be a continous map. The pullback bundle is defined to be

f∗L:={(x,l)∈(X,L):f(x)=p(l)}⊆X×L,f^{\ast}\mathcal{L} := \{ (x,l) \in (X,\mathcal{L}) : f(x) = p(l) \} \subseteq X \times \mathcal{L}, f∗L:={(x,l)∈(X,L):f(x)=p(l)}⊆X×L,

which is equipped with the subspace topology and the projection map π:f∗L→X\pi : f^{\ast}\mathcal{L} \rightarrow Xπ:f∗L→X, given by projecting onto the first factor.

# Direct Sum of Bundles

Let L\mathcal{L}L and M\mathcal{M}M be two vector bundles over XXX. The direct sum L⊕M\mathcal{L} \oplus \mathcal{M}L⊕M is the vector bundle over XXX whose fibre (L⊕M)x(\mathcal{L} \oplus \mathcal{M})_{x}(L⊕M)x​ for any x∈Xx \in Xx∈X is canonically isomorphic to Lx⊕Mx\mathcal{L}_{x} \oplus \mathcal{M}_{x}Lx​⊕Mx​ as vector spaces.

# Tensor Product of Bundles

Let L\mathcal{L}L and M\mathcal{M}M be two vector bundles over XXX. The tensor product L⊗M\mathcal{L} \otimes \mathcal{M}L⊗M is the vector bundle over XXX whose fibre (L⊗M)x(\mathcal{L} \otimes \mathcal{M})_{x}(L⊗M)x​ for any x∈Xx \in Xx∈X is canonically isomorphic to Lx⊗Mx\mathcal{L}_{x} \otimes \mathcal{M}_{x}Lx​⊗Mx​ as vector spaces.

# Exterior and Symmetric Powers of Bundles

Let L\mathcal{L}L be a vector bundle over XXX. The iii-th exterior power ⋀iL⋀^{i}\mathcal{L}⋀iL and the iii-th symmetric power SiLS^{i}\mathcal{L}SiL are the vector bundles over XXX whose fibres for any x∈Xx \in Xx∈X are canonically isomorphic to ⋀iLx⋀^{i}\mathcal{L}_{x}⋀iLx​ and SiLxS^{i}\mathcal{L}_{x}SiLx​, respectively.

# External Tensor Products of Bundles

For two vector bundles p1:L→Xp_{1}: \mathcal{L} \rightarrow Xp1​:L→X and p2:M→Yp_{2}: \mathcal{M} \rightarrow Yp2​:M→Y, their external tensor product, denoted by

L⊠M→X×Y,\mathcal{L} \boxtimes \mathcal{M} \rightarrow X \times Y, L⊠M→X×Y,

is the tensor product of vector bundles of the pullback bundles p1∗L⊗Xp2∗M→X×Yp_{1}^{\ast}\mathcal{L} \otimes_{X} p_{2}^{\ast}\mathcal{M} \rightarrow X \times Yp1∗​L⊗X​p2∗​M→X×Y over the product space X×YX \times YX×Y.

# Dual Bundles

Let L\mathcal{L}L be a vector bundle over XXX. The dual bundle L∗\mathcal{L}^{\ast}L∗ is the vector bundle over XXX whose fibre (L∗)x(\mathcal{L}^{\ast})_{x}(L∗)x​ over x∈Xx \in Xx∈X is canonically isomorphic with the dual vector space (Lx)∗(\mathcal{L}_{x})^{\ast}(Lx​)∗.

# Determinant Bundles

Let L\mathcal{L}L be a vector bundle over XXX of rank rrr. The determinant bundle of L\mathcal{L}L is the line bundle det⁡(L):=⋀rL\det(\mathcal{L}) := ⋀^{r}\mathcal{L}det(L):=⋀rL.

# Projective Bundles

Let L\mathcal{L}L be a vector bundle over XXX, and let s:X→Ls : X \rightarrow \mathcal{L}s:X→L be the zero section of L\mathcal{L}L, that is any point x∈Xx \in Xx∈X is mapped to 0∈Lx0 \in \mathcal{L}_{x}0∈Lx​ by sss. The projective bundle associated to L\mathcal{L}L, or the projectivisation of L\mathcal{L}L, is defined as

P(L):=(L−s(X))/C∗,\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{L}) := (\mathcal{L} - s(X))/\mathbb{C}^{\ast}, P(L):=(L−s(X))/C∗,

and it comes with a projective π:P(L)→X\pi: \mathbb{P}(\mathcal{L}) \rightarrow Xπ:P(L)→X whose fibre over x∈Xx \in Xx∈X is isomorphic to the projectivised vector space P(Lx)\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{L}_{x})P(Lx​).
